88.cons: Management is slow to invest in technology because they seem to focus on the immediate ROI instead of seeing the long term payoff. Lack of clear expectations by management, which result in a general free for all with everyone trying to work on anything and everything in hopes that it will gain them visibility in the organization. And expect to have hundreds of emails bombard your inbox that you may not even read because at some point you might get asked a question and you have to scour your inbox for some information, but if you can’t find that information someone is going to complain that they weren’t kept up to date on whatever they wanted to know about. It feels like a race to make everything off shore to spend as little as possible. Some teams are probably better than others. Unfortunately favoritism seems to run rampant in some teams probably encouraged by the constant jostling among team members to get their name out there.

761.desc: Great place to grow and learn
761.pros: Start-up mindset is thrown around at a lot of places. Here’s a place that has grown so rapidly that there are still big, significant changes needed all over the place. There’s something almost charming about the less formed aspects of the place. The office NEEDS its tech employees. And while comp can seem to be on the low end initially, the numbers are not accurate, or the best way to look at things. Stick around for a few review cycles, and your career will benefit enormously. If nothing else, Uber will teach you a work ethic that is priceless and will make you enormously valuable anywhere else.

830.pros: Exploring innovative ways to explore career growth that aren’t linear but more or leas experienced based. Autonomy is great and many people dictate their own schedule - less true if you work in HQ. Compensation is great and it’s difficult to find better comp outside but of course there’s equity that drives value. Using Unlimited PTO is encouraged.
830.cons: Upward career growth is difficult to achieve. Everyone wants to manage and move to the next level. Uber is a level driven company where everyone works hard to be promoted. WLB can fluctuate - peaks and valleys. We’re still complaining that there’s no 401K match. Company culture is going through hell. Following layoffs we have no idea who we are. We do not show up as one team and people are burnt out leading to high attrition. There’s a struggle between a company that wants to be mature but that also values moving fast and getting shit done which the latter breeds a different type of person that a mature company does not. Management! Oh my goodness, I love Uber but management is terrible. Young or inexperienced, self-seeking, lack of experience in developing / coaching, and some very bad attitudes make up the leaders at Uber. Enter at your own risk and get ready for a wild ride!

1035.cons: Day-to-day, your experience can be great and mileage vary depending on your local team. Uber has a lot going for it, but at a high-level, it shoots itself in the foot by not taking care of its own. One would think that after layoffs, the company would spend more time listening and investing in the tenured folks who remain, but attrition and churn continue to run high. 1400.desc: Fantastic place to work in the right team
1400.pros: With the right manager/ skip Uber is a fantastic place to work. My WLB is excellent even with high priority projects on our teams plate. People make the most of unlimited leave (4-5 weeks on average for my team) and the perks are good.If you want to work for a big company where there is still the potential for big, individual impact, and the stock has potential for huge growth the Uber is a great place to work.
1400.cons: Some teams/individuals value doing high impact work for promos over good engineering and it leads to sloppy code and poorly maintained systems. 1510.pros: - Some incredibly smart engineers! - Cool internal infra: they give you the tools to hack shit up quick- Comp can seem high on paper (company trajectory is meh and future uncertain)- Managers will make you feel like they can give you growth, which feels exciting. Don't fall for this.
1510.cons: - Toxic. Toxic. Toxic. I dont even know where to start. e.g. --> Aggresive culture: My TL threw his keys at me in a meeting when I couldnt meet a deadline after pushing diffs at 4am and working weekends for monfhs on end to meet a deadline my pushbacks were never taken seriously for. He would stare and grunt at me in meetings if I spoke too much and stole any attention.--> Toe-stepping still encouraged. People will tell you you're leading a project only to secretly create their own project plans and get your project cancelled.--> Ugly politics. People will lie to manuever their way into the right political alliances. Both your teammates and your manager.- The company doesnt care about you. You will realize this on your first day. It's in the air. I made 4 friends during onboarding - 2 of them voluntarily left within 2 months and 1 of them got laid off. - Frontline management is a joke.The company gives them almost no power or no knowledge of whats really happening. Attrition is ridiculous (my manager, skip and his skip all left in my first 7 months). Technical orgs often get managers from product orgs who just simply lack the technical vision to get teams to work together. When manager changes, you basically start proving yourself all over again in your current level. Note: I learnt a lot in my time at the company and met some very great engineers I will always stay in touch with. However, some of my experiences were almost unbelievably dramatic and I want to make sure I highlight this to people before they consider joining.

1661.desc: Used to be a great company, but not any more
1661.pros: Smart people, solving interesting problems, your work directly impact people's daily life.Free food is OK.
1661.cons: CEO is not the funder, he does not have the bond to the company & employees as other leaders. Look at the CEO of Airbnb. Although he always deny, I still think he is working to please the wall street and stake holders. I don't really agree with his vision by permanently cut so many jobs during pandemic. Management team has done this back and forth without learning from mistakes. Last year, layoff, then hire crazily with extra amount of refer bonus, there are still tons of positions can not be filled in several months. Now cut so many jobs again, how is the company going to compete after economy recover? So many talented engineers with years of experiences are let go, it's very hard to hire this kind of talent people back. True you can use higher package to attract people who care about TC after recovery, however the lost of knowledge and the damage to the reputation as a tech company can never roll back. As an engineer, I would never want to work for Uber again.
1661.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  j****  Software Engineer, Platform - Jun 16, 2020
